items.title: Get rid of (or streamline) safeweakref

milestone.title: Envisage 5.0.0
milestone.description:
This milestone is for issues and PRs that will be addressed for the 5.0.0 release.

Primary aims of 5.0.0:

- Remove Python 2 support.
- Other backwards incompatible removals and deprecations, while avoiding gratuitous breakage.

items.body:
There are two aspects of the safeweakref module:

- provide `WeakMethod`, which isn't available in Python 2
- cache weak method references by the object they live on

I believe that the cache is unnecessary, and since we no longer support Python 2, we can get `WeakMethod` from the standard library; those two changes should significantly streamline the code.

I'd also like to move away from the "safeweakref is a drop-in replacement for weakref" design.

items.title: Test suite fails against Traits master
items.body:
The test suite currently fails when run against the master branch of Traits.

One cause of failures is addressed in #255.
Another cause appears to be an open bug in Traits: enthought/traits#793.

Once those are fixed, there may still be other failures.

items.title: Consider deprecating/remove the TwistedApplication
items.body:
The [TwistedApplication](https://github.com/enthought/envisage/blob/master/envisage/twisted_application.py) seems to have been an experiment which lives on the master branch. There are no tests that I can find for it.

We might want to deprecate and remove it from the codebase.

Note that if the module gets removed, we will also need to remove it from the `envisage.api`.

items.title: Str/Bytes incompatibility in single_project

milestone.title: Envisage 5.0.0
milestone.description:
This milestone is for issues and PRs that will be addressed for the 5.0.0 release.

Primary aims of 5.0.0:

- Remove Python 2 support.
- Other backwards incompatible removals and deprecations, while avoiding gratuitous breakage.

items.body:
In the `envisage.ui.single_project` code, the following line appears to cause issues with type mismatch:

https://github.com/enthought/envisage/blob/master/envisage/ui/single_project/project.py#L215

* `clean_filename()` returns bytes
* `get_default_path()` returns unicode

So these two can not be joined on [line 216](https://github.com/enthought/envisage/blob/master/envisage/ui/single_project/project.py#L216)

To reproduce the error - create a new python3 env and install the latest `envisage` (4.9.0), then do the following:

```
>>> import envisage
>>> envisage.__version__
'4.9.0'
>>> from envisage.ui.single_project.project import Project
>>> class MyProject(Project):
            pass
>>> prj = MyProject()
>>> loc = prj.get_default_project_location(None)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/mgrady/.edm/envs/test-envisage/lib/python3.6/site-packages/envisage/ui/single_project/project.py", line 216, in get_default_project_location
    location = os.path.join(path, name)
  File "/Users/mgrady/.edm/envs/test-envisage/Resources/Python.app/Contents/MacOS/../../../../lib/python3.6/posixpath.py", line 94, in join
    genericpath._check_arg_types('join', a, *p)
  File "/Users/mgrady/.edm/envs/test-envisage/Resources/Python.app/Contents/MacOS/../../../../lib/python3.6/genericpath.py", line 151, in _check_arg_types
    raise TypeError("Can't mix strings and bytes in path components") from None
TypeError: Can't mix strings and bytes in path components
```

PR to follow shortly resolving this issue.

items.title: PluginTestCase is modifying/leaving files in application home
items.body:
By default, application home on mac osx is `~/.enthought`. Running the `TestPlugin` will produce create the `test` sub directory in `~/.enthought` and an empty `preferences.ini` file. Further `test` will contain two empty sub directories `A` and `B`.

```
$ ls ~/.enthought/test/
plugins		preferences.ini
$ ls ~/.enthought/test/plugins/
A	B
(bootstrap)bash-3.2$
```

items.title: IPythonKernelPlugin: allow for the possibility that `IPython.utils.io` streams don't exist.
items.body: The tests of an application using the `IPythonKernelPlugin` started failing after updating to the latest version of Envisage. That application was deleting `IPython.utils.io.stdout` and friends. It shouldn't have been doing that, but equally, the `IPythonKernelPlugin` should be robust against such changes (and the `IPython.utils.io` attributes are deprecated and could conceivably be removed in a future version of the `IPython` package).

items.title: Test suite leaks file descriptors.
items.body: The IPython-related tests leak approximately 20 file descriptors per test. Once there are enough tests, this causes the OS to run out of file descriptors. We're seeing this particularly on Travis CI, where the number of available file descriptors per process is apparently relatively small.

items.title: Remove envisage.categories extension point
items.body:
A future version of Traits is likely to remove support for categories. At that point, we should remove the `envisage.categories` extension point from the core plugin.

This should likely be part of a post-2019 Python 3-only Envisage release, with a major version number bump.

items.title: RefreshCodePlugin is non-functional
items.body:
The `RefreshCodePlugin` is currently non-functional (and has been so since Envisage 3): it imports `envisage.PluginDefinition`, which doesn't exist.

It needs to be either abandoned and deleted, or resurrected and tested.

items.title: IPythonShellView has broken imports
items.body: The `IPythonShellView` does `from IPython.kernel.core.interpreter import Interpreter`, but there's no such module `IPython.kernel.core`.

items.title: Documentation: make key classes available for intersphinx
items.body: Key classes like `Plugin` and `ExtensionPoint` are not currently available in https://docs.enthought.com/envisage/objects.inv, meaning that it's not possible to refer to those classes from other projects via the `sphinx.ext.intersphinx` extension.

items.title: etstool.py won't work from a non-EDM environment on Windows
items.body: `etstool.py` is unnecessarily restrictive in that it only works in an EDM environment on Windows. A fix is to invoke `edm.bat` instead of `edm.exe` in the subprocess calls.

items.title: setup.py attempts to import from envisage._version
items.body:
In the following code, we attempt to import from the `_version` module; we should `exec` its contents instead.

Code: https://github.com/enthought/envisage/blob/361167ab74e93d1d5739c9a75cb029af8ce02f52/setup.py#L92-L93

See also: enthought/traitsui#549, enthought/traits#478

items.title: Setting always_use_default_layout will never use the default layout if there is an application_memento file
items.body:
Setting `self.always_use_default_layout=True` seems like it should use the default layout specified and not load the previous state. However, the opposite behaviour happens in practice.

The problem seems to be that in `create_windows` the `restore` argument is `restore=self.always_use_default_layout`, but it should be `restore=not self.always_use_default_layout` as setting `restore=True` means `self._restore_layout_from_state` gets called, restoring things from a previous state and not using the default layout as requested.

items.title: String repr for ExtensionPoint instances
items.body: Currently `ExtensionPoint` reprs use the standard Python repr i.e. `'<envisage.extension_point.ExtensionPoint object at 0x7f125d4ce550>'`, which is not useful in anyway. It would be nice if `__str__` returns the `ExtensionPoint.id` attribute.

items.title: Drop support for Python 2.6, Python 3.3, Python 3.4
items.body:
Dropping support for outdated versions of Python (2.6, 3.3, 3.4) is long overdue, and is already partially complete.

- [x] Remove support in Travis, Appveyor and `etstool.py` (already done)
- [ ] Remove unnecessary eggs from `envisage/tests/eggs` and `envisage/tests/bad_eggs`
- [ ] Document Python version requirements clearly somewhere (possibly in the README is good enough)
- [ ] (Possibly) add explicit sys.version check in `setup.py`

See also #83, where CI support for Python 2.6 was removed.

items.title: Remove the envisage.developer package
items.body:
The envisage.developer package appears to contain experimental, incomplete, untested and non-working code. @rahulporuri recently fixed a `NameError` in one of the modules (resulting from the use of `Hastraits` instead of `HasTraits`) that would have prevented it even from being imported at any time over the last 11 years. (See #130.)

I propose that we remove this package completely.

items.title: single_project plugin uses deprecated adaptation machinery
items.body: The `single_project` plugin uses the outdated and deprecated `adapts` machinery. which will be removed in Traits 5.0.0. The code should be updated to use the newer adaptation patterns.

items.title: Application.get_extensions gives infinite recursion against Traits master
items.body:
The following script gives a `RecursionError` when run against Traits master. The change which triggered this looks very likely to be enthought/traits#382. The recursion seems to be a result of this change mixed with the `inspect` magic used by Envisage.

Here's the script
```python
from envisage.api import Application, ExtensionPoint, Plugin
from traits.api import List

class PluginA(Plugin):
    id = 'A'
    x  = ExtensionPoint(List, id='bob')

application = Application(plugins=[PluginA()])
application.get_extensions('bob')
```

items.title: Include Jupyter packages in CI setup.
items.body:
Since the CI rework in #111, 4 tests are being skipped on all platforms. Those tests are related to the Jupyter/IPython plugins. We should extend the CI setup so that those tests are executed.

Note that the tests fail with the most recent versions of Jupyter, so there's some investigation and bug fixing to be done here too.

items.title: Tests are unnecessarily noisy
items.body: The envisage test suite sends a lot of output to stdout. That output obscures warnings that might indicate an actual issue, and makes it hard to see the failures and errors. It would be good to clean this up where possible.

items.title: CI broken on master
items.body:
Our continuous integration appears to be broken on master, as the runs for #109 show. We're seeing a variety of failure modes.

- [ ] 2.7_with_system_site_packages uses an ancient version of Python 2.7 (2.7.6), and tornado complains about an out-of-date SSL for that version.
- [ ] Many failures on Python 3.x related to current Jupyter packages. (See also #107).

items.title: Old-style relative import ipython_kernel plugin
items.body:
There's an old-style import here:

https://github.com/enthought/envisage/blob/7cb070da77d79aa37e132a3d44e55c3e593f627f/envisage/plugins/ipython_kernel/api.py#L1

Apparently this isn't being picked up by the tests, so we need a fix and a regression test.

items.title: InternalIPKernel.shutdown method doesn't stop the kernel's IOPubThread
items.body:
In recent versions of IPython (tested with `ipkernel` version 4.5.2), the `InternalIPKernel.shutdown` method doesn't stop the kernel's `IOPubThread`. I suspect that a line that looks something like:
```
self.ipkernel.iopub_thread.stop()
```
needs to be added to that method.

items.body:
When running the envisage tests under python 3.5 we have a good amount of failures.

(see https://travis-ci.org/enthought/envisage/jobs/193117479)

items.title: Python 3 issue with saving Tasks app state
items.body:
Reported by Eric McDonald:

```
File "C:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\envisage\ui\tasks\tasks_application.py", line 315, in _load_state 
restored_state = pickle.load(f) 
TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'str'
```

and similar errors.  Reported fix is that files need to be opened in `rb` mode (which I think is bug in Python 2.7 as well - things probably aren't working as expected under Windows in some situations!)

items.title: No ets repo for 4.4.0?
items.body: I don't see envisage-4.4.0.tar.gz at http://www.enthought.com/repo/ets/

items.title: Adapt Envisage to new adaptation mechanism.
items.body: The Envisage source still makes heavy use of 'implements';  this causes distracting Traits deprecation warnings for applications using Envisage.

items.title: Warn on failed service lookups?
items.body:
We discovered recently that two service lookups in our Envisage application had been failing (i.e., returning `None`) for a while, thanks to misspelled `protocol` strings, without us noticing.

Would it be worth issuing a `logger.warn` for failed service lookups?

items.title: License headers
items.body: It would be good if all source files could contain the proper license header in the file.  This greatly helps with license audits.

items.title: "Lorenz" example not working
items.body:
I just installed Envisage from the latest available Debian packages, version 4.0.0-1.  The "Lorenz" example plots only once, and never updates the plot.  The following exception is logged:

```
Exception occurred in traits notification handler for object: <acme.lorenz.lorenz.Lorenz object at 0xa23e3bc>, trait: time, old value: [  0.00000000e+00   1.00000000e+02   1.00000000e-02], new value: [u'0.0' u'100.' u'0.01']
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/traits/trait_notifiers.py", line 360, in call_1
    self.handler( object )
  File "/home/sven/tmp/Lorenz/acme/lorenz/lorenz.py", line 38, in _time_changed
    def _time_changed(self): self.refresh()
  File "/home/sven/tmp/Lorenz/acme/lorenz/lorenz.py", line 29, in refresh
    self.calculatePoints()
  File "/home/sven/tmp/Lorenz/acme/lorenz/lorenz.py", line 49, in calculatePoints
    self.timePoints = arange(*self.time)
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for -: 'numpy.unicode_' and 'numpy.unicode_'
```

I can make the example partly work by naively replacing the failing line with

```
self.timePoints = arange(*self.time.astype(float))
```

Other exceptions will still occur with this "fix" in place, though.

items.title: incompatible with ipython 0.11
items.body:
envisage/plugins/ipython_shell/view/ipython_shell_view.py uses the old ipython api:

```
line 9: from IPython.kernel.core.interpreter import Interpreter
```

IPython.kernel has been replaced by IPython.parallel in ipython 0.11.
Unfortunately Interpreter class does not exist anymore and I don't know with what it was replaced.
